Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: SusChEM: An industrial-academic collaboration for high throughput discovery of base metal catalysts
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this Grant Opportunities for Academic Liasons with Industry (GOALI) project funded by the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Paul Chirik of Princeton University in full collaboration with Dr. Matt Tudge and his colleagues at Merck will develop base metal catalysts for drug discovery and production. The proposed research focuses on the asymmetric olefin hydrogenation reaction, a key transformation for the synthesis of single enantiomer organic molecules with biological activity. In collaboration with scientists at Merck, high throughput experimentation will be employed to identify metal-ligand combinations that exhibit high catalytic activity and enantioselectivity. Once suitable catalysts are identified, the Princeton group will independently synthesize and isolate these compounds and elucidate their electronic structure through a combination of spectroscopic, magnetic, structural and computational studies. The broader impacts of this research will include the exposure of undergraduate and graduate students to an industrial research setting at the Merck research site in Rahway, NJ.

Chirality, the handedness of a molecule, often dictates the biological function of a molecule. Pharmaceuticals often contain chiral molecules and frequently require the challenging synthesis of a single hand of the compound of interest. Transition metal catalysts are known to catalyze reactions such as the hydrogenation of alkenes to produce the desired mirror image form. The proposed research seeks to discover metal catalysts that employ earth abundant and inexpensive elements such as iron and cobalt, a key innovation in sustainable sciences and technology. The project will also allow for integration of manufacturing principles into curricula for the classroom as well as provide undergraduate and graduate students a unique experience in an industrial laboratory.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
Transition metal-catalyzed chemical reactions have transformed modern society by enabling the synthesis of consumer products ranging from modern materials and electronics to medicines that improve quality of life. For decades, catalyst technology has relied on some of the least abundant elements in the Earth’s crust – palladium, platinum, rhodium, and iridium. In addition to their high cost, price volatility, and toxicity, extraction and purification of these elements has significant environmental consequences. It has been estimated that obtaining one ounce of platinum for example, often requires mining approximately 10 tons of ore which creates a CO2 footprint that is estimated to be 6,000 times that of abundant metals such as iron.

 

Using earth abundant, first row transition metals such as iron, nickel and cobalt in place of precious metal raises many important fundamental chemical questions. How does one transform the function of the earth abundant metal to mimic or ideally exceed the performance of the precious metal? Are there new catalytic transformations that exploit the unique electronic properties of earth abundant metals that are unknown with precious metals? In collaboration with researchers in the Catalysis Discovery group at Merck, our NSF funded GOALI program has focused on the discovery of earth abundant transition metal catalysts for new routes to medicinally relevant compounds. Specifically, our primary focus has been asymmetric alkene hydrogenation, a reaction that accounts for approximately 50% of the chiral material in the drug industry and is a key component of sustainable chemistry.  A second area of our work has involved the radiolabeling of pharmaceuticals and iron catalysts have been discovered that provide a new diagnostic for drug safety and registration.

 

The intellectual merit of our NSF GOALI program has resulted in a fundamental understanding of how to manipulate the flow of electrons with earth abundant transition metals to enable new catalytic reaction chemistry. These discoveries have been accelerated by the use of high throughput experimentation, a technique available in the Merck Catalysis Laboratory. Princeton undergraduate and graduate students became fully versed in these techniques and gained a unique experience that is outside the typical academic curriculum. This combined industrial-academic approach has resulted in the discovery of cobalt and nickel catalysts that operate in environmentally friendly solvents with activity and selectivity that rival the most widely used rhodium and iridium catalysts. A cobalt catalyst was recently discovered and applied to the enantioselective synthesis of levitiracetam, an epilepsy treatment. Mechanistic studies, conducted at an accelerated pace with high throughput experimentation, established a unique Co(0)-Co(II) cycle, a pathway distinct from know precious metal catalysts. Related nickel catalysts have also been discovered that form unusual trimetallic compounds, again distinct from established precious reactivity. The lessons learned from these studies extended beyond catalytic asymmetric hydrogenation and have broader impact in providing new design principals for catalysis with earth abundant transition metals.

 

The NSF-suppored academic-industrial collaboration also open new educational and outreach opportunities. Merck PIs have established new undergraduate internships through our program as well as career development workshops at Princeton focused specifically on engaging female researchers in chemistry. Princeton undergraduate and graduate students have gained important industrial experience, including Merck safety training as well as opportunities for presentations to broader audiences.

Modified by: Paul J Chirik
